entry.title: The early history of water injection into internal combustion engines
entry.summary: Contrary to some common belief, the interest of injecting liquid water into internal combustion engines is actually as old as this engines. However, the original goal of such a strategy was not exactly the same as it is nowadays.
entry.content:
Introduction

It is quite usual for authors of scientific papers dealing with water injection applied to internal combustion engines (ICE), to date back the invention of this process to its famous application on some supercharged WW2 aircraft engines1. However, this idea actually dates from the very beginning of the ICE history, and its initial goal was quite different from the current one. But before getting to the heart of the matter, let us say few words about the early ages of ICE.

According to Zima2, the first ICE were developed during the second half of the XIX century as alternative sources of mechanical power, cheaper than the expensive steam engines. Logically, their practical use were based on available and inexpensive fuels as well. The fuels consumed by such engines were then often heterogeneous, composed by gaseous (hydrogen, lighting gas, liquid heavy oils) and sometimes solid components, as coal dusts3. The nowadays usual light fractions of crude oil, including gasoline, have been indeed available for engines only since the late 1800s4 The combustions of such fuels were actually often ‘brutal’, producing too high temperatures and were difficult to control. This issue led some engineers of these days to look for a way to dilute and ‘slow down’ the chemical energy hence released.

The Lenoir engine

Probably because it has been the first ICE to be commercialized at a relatively large scale, with about 5000 engines built, the Lenoir engine, see below, invented by Étienne Lenoir, is one of the most famous.

Footnotes

  1. Rowe, M. R. and Ladd, G. T., Water Injection for Aircraft Engines, SAE Technical Paper, 460192, doi:10.4271/460192, 1946. ↩
  2. Zima, S., Internal Combustion Engine Handbook, chapter 1: Historical Review, SAE International, 2004. ↩
  3. Lawton, B., The Piston Engine Revolution, chapter 9: Some Early Internal Combustion Engines, The Newcomen Society, 2011. ↩
  4. Heywood, J. B., Internal Combustion Engine Fundamentals, McGraw-Hill, 1988. ↩

entry.title: Beautiful view inside a spark ignited engine
entry.summary: Beautiful view through a transparent spark ignited combustion engine, explaining few things about technology and fundamental thermodynamics.
entry.content: I recently found an interesting video of the inside of a transparent spark ignited four stroke internal combustion engine, from the amazing SmarterEveryDay youtube channel. From a technical point of view, this animation is very interesting because we can clearly see where the spark plug is (the tiny blue dot) and how it works, i.e. how it triggers the combustion process. Moreover, from a more ‘thermodynamics’ standpoint, we can also approximately compare the speed of the flame front with the one of the piston. Clearly, the flame propagates itself in almost all the clearance volume while the piston just moves a little. The combustion process occurs then in an almost constant volume, and it’s why we usually suppose it as isochoric.
